question: Does genetic ablation or disruption of osteocytes impair G-CSF–induced mobilization of hematopoietic stem/progenitor cells in mice? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF), used clinically to mobilize HSPCs, induces changes in the morphology and gene expression of the osteocytic network that precedes changes in osteoblasts.
content.source_2: In mice with conditional ablation of DMP1+ osteocytes, G-CSF administration produced typical elevations of circulating c-Kit+ Sca-1+ Lin− HSPCs, demonstrating that osteocytes are dispensable for mobilization.
content.source_3: Mice with targeted ablation of osteocytes or a disrupted osteocyte network have comparable numbers of HSPCs in the BM but fail to mobilize HSPCs in response to G-CSF.
content.source_4: Longitudinal imaging and transcriptomic profiling showed that neither acute nor prolonged G-CSF exposure altered osteocyte morphology or gene expression; HSPC egress correlated solely with osteoblast suppression and CXCL12 downregulation.
